Graphical abstract In this work we compare the performance of platinum and palladium co-catalysts supported on Nb-doped titania materials for the photo-generation of hydrogen using methanol as sacrificial agent. Liquid and gas phase processes are considered. The catalysts physico-chemical properties were characterized by a combination of X-ray diffraction, UV–vis and photoluminescence spectroscopies and transmission electron microscopy, and their photocatalytic performance assessed through the analysis of the optical properties, the measurement of the reaction rates and subsequent computation of the true quantum efficiency in both liquid and gas phase reactors. Using Pt and Pd containing catalysts having similar primary noble metal particle size we compare the two co-catalysts performance in terms of the carbon containing product selectivity of the methanol photo-transformation and the overall performance of the materials in the photon to chemical transformation as measured through the true quantum efficiency. The work shows that Pd displays competitive performance with respect to Pt under UV illumination but not under visible light. The physico-chemical analysis of the solids and particularly the measurement of the charge carrier handling and recombination through photoluminescence at several wavelengths indicate the important role played by charge recombination upon UV illumination but also that other phenomena need to be considered under visible illumination to fully explain the photo-catalytic evolution of hydrogen in noble metal containing catalysts. Keywords Anatase Quantum efficiency and yield Selectivity UV Visible Sunlight 1 Introduction Hydrogen production from renewable sources is a key technology for achieving a greener future and to contribute to build up a sustainable society. Photocatalysis can provide an attractive alternative for the renewable production of hydrogen using light and bio-molecules [1–5]. Several bio-alcohols have been tested in such a process, being those having at least one hydrogen atom bonded to the (carbon) alpha position the ones rendering higher reaction rates [6–18]. Among those, methanol is the simple one from a chemical point of view and probably the molecule receiving most attention due to the relatively high hydrogen production rates commonly observed [19–22]. Titania-based materials have customarily used in photocatalysis due to a number of properties including their relatively low cost, high availability, and significant activity in all reactions tested and, particularly, in hydrogen production from water resources using bio-alcohols as sacrificial agents [1–5,23]. In photochemical and more frequently in photoelectrochemical processes, doping of titania with Nb has been used to enhance charge transport and mobility, particularly concerning electron-related species [24,25]. This aspect is potentially important in the hydrogen production process as it requires as a key step the proton reduction to drive to the hydrogen molecule formation. In the hydrogen photocatalytic production using titania based materials the use of a metallic co-catalyst has been shown to boost significantly activity [1,4,26,27]. Platinum is the most studied noble metal co-catalysts due to its high effectiveness. According to the previous works, Pt activity has its roots in a significant number of physico-chemical phenomena including those related to morphology and associated to primary particle size, shape, interface contact with the anatase and related (charge handling) properties between the metal and the oxide, as well as electron-acceptor properties of the metal phase itself and subsequent beneficial effects in charge recombination [13,15,20–22,28–40]. Pt has the higher work function among noble metals, and would thus drive to a stronger electron transfer with titania, as well as displays the lowest energy for proton reduction, two facts which would make it a reasonable choice for the photo-generation of hydrogen [41]. However, in several works comparing noble metals, Pd has shown to provide higher activity than Pt, at least per metal atom basis [11,38,42]. On the other hand, Pd activity in hydrogen production with the help of sacrificial molecules has been also extensively studied, rendering essentially the same conclusions in respect to the activity physical origin than the above discussed platinum case [43–47]. The comparison of Pt and Pd is therefore complex due to the number of physico-chemical properties affecting activity. Here we will carry out this comparison with samples having virtually the same metal primary particle size as determined by a multitechnique characterization analysis of the materials. This last point would facilitate a meaningful comparison of results. Moreover, we will carry out the reaction using methanol at liquid and gas phases (similarly to reforming processes in thermal catalysis) and under UV and Visible light excitation. Both types of processes have been tested in the literature for the same catalysts but result mostly concerns reaction rate measurements [48]. To adequately compare the results of the different reactors and light excitation sources, not only a physico-chemical similar co-catalyst is required but also the calculation of the true quantum efficiency is mandatory to obtain a meaningful comparison. The latter is presented here and demands; i) the full analysis of the optical properties of the catalysts both at a liquid media as well as a supported thin film, as well as ii) the modeling of the light-matter interaction at the corresponding reaction medium [49]. To compare both noble metal co-catalysts, we also consider the carbon-containing products generated from methanol as hydrogen is co-produced from such molecules with different stoichiometric ratios. This clearly indicates that the surface chemistry of the methanol transformation affect the hydrogen production and this has been only considered in rather specific examples in the literature [20,38]. The noble metal Pt and Pd co-catalysts will be supported in a high surface area Nb-doped titania support prepared using a microwave method followed by a spray drying and calcination process. In previous tests, such preparation procedure yielded high active titania-based photocatalysts tested in pollutant elimination reactions [50,51]. 2 Material and methods 2.1 Preparation and characterization of catalysts Catalysts preparation was carried out in a propylene vial containing a mixture of 46.5wt.% of ethanol (Industrial grade), 8.3wt.% of titanium butoxide (Aldrich, 97.00%), certain amount of ammonium niobate (V) oxalate hydrate (3wt.% of Niobium in respect of the final material; Aldrich, 99.99%), and 55.3wt.% of deionized water. The mixture was transferred and heated at 160°C for 2min under microwave irradiation by using a microwave reactor (Anton Paar, model Synthos 3000). The suspension obtained from de microwave reactor was atomized through a 2mm nozzle in a YAMATO spray dryer (model DL410), at 2bar and 200°C. After drying, each sample received a thermal treatment at 500°C in air during 2h. The co-catalysts were introduced by a deposition method using H2PtCl6 (Aldrich) and PdNO3 (Aldrich) solution. First, the sample was suspended by stirring in a deionized water solution for 30min. After that, the proper quantity of H2PtCl6 or PdNO3 was added to the solution (to get a 0.4mol% of M=Pt/Pd on metal basis) and kept on stirring along 5min more. This loading corresponds to a 1wt.% of Pt, a loading typically used in these materials. The reduction was carried out using a NaBH4 (Aldrich) aqueous solution (M/NaBH4 molar ratio 1/5). The final solid was rinsed with deionized water, collected by centrifugation and dried at 80°C. The nomenclature used to identify the materials is: 3NbTi for the support, 3NbTi/Pt and 3NbTi/Pd for the corresponding catalysts. Chemical analysis provided a metal concentration of 0.4mol% for both co-catalysts, equal within an error of 3.5%. For preliminary catalytic tests, we prepared samples having different Pt and Nb contents in, respectively, ranges between 0.2–0.6 and 1–5mol%. XRD profiles of the samples were obtained using a Policristal X́Pert Pro PANalytical diffractometer using Ni-filtered Cu Kα radiation with a 0.02° step. The particle sizes were estimated using XRD using the Willianson–Hall formalism. The BET surface areas and average pore sizes and pore volumes were measured by nitrogen physisorption (Micromeritics ASAP 2010). UV-vis diffuse-reflectance spectroscopy experiments were performed on a Shimadzu UV2100 apparatus using BaSO4 as a reference. Photoluminescence spectra were measured at room temperature on a Fluorescence Spectrophotometer (Perkin Elmer LS50B). Transmission electron microscopy (HTEM) and X-ray energy dispersive spectra (XEDS) were recorded on a JEOL 2100F TEM/STEM microscope. Particle size distributions of the noble metal were obtained counting more than 150 particles in all cases. 2.2 Description of reactors Regarding photocatalytic measurements at liquid medium, they were carried out using a batch pyrex (cutting absorption edge at ca. 300nm) reactor as depicted in Fig. S1 of the Supporting information section. The reactor contains a 3:7 (v/v) MeOH/H2O mixture medium maintained at a constant temperature (20±1 °C). The catalyst suspension (0.5gL−1) was first degassed with an Ar stream for around 20min. Subsequently, the Ar flow was settled down to 10mLmin−1 and stabilized before reaction. Ar is used as carrier to displace reaction gases from the reactor to the detection system. The solution inside a reactor was irradiated using a Hg-Xe lamp (500W) and dichroic filters (LOT Quantum Design) allowing exposure of the catalysis to the UV (280–400nm) or Visible (420–680nm) wavelength range. The reaction rates for hydrogen production were evaluated at 3h from the start of the irradiation, where a pseudo-stationary situation is reached. Gas-phase reaction was carried in a continuous flow annular photoreactor containing ca. 0.4mgcm−2 of photocatalyst as a thin layer coating on a pyrex tube. Gas and liquid phase use the same amount of catalyst per experiment. The scheme of the reactor is shown in Fig. S4 of the Supporting information section. After degassing the line with Ar, the flow was settled down to 10mLmin−1 and stabilized before reaction. A 3:7 (v/v) MeOH/H2O mixture was achieved with a carrier having saturated water content. Water was injected with a syringe pump and the corresponding methanol content using a saturator at controlled temperature. Photocatalytic experiments were carried out under UV-A light irradiation (Sylvania F6WBLT-65; 6W) or visible irradiation (Philips TL54-765; 6W). In both cases, four fluorescent lamps symmetrically positioned outside the photo-reactor were used (see configuration at Supporting information section, Fig. S4). Reaction rates for hydrogen production were evaluated under steady-state conditions, typically achieved after ca. 3–6h from the irradiation starting. In both set-ups, the hydrogen rate was analyzed using an on-line Mass spectrometry (Onmistart 300), gas (TCD/FID detection using HP-PLOT-Q/HP-Innowax columns and an Agilent 6890 apparatus) and liquid chromatography (xD8-C18/5 microm, 4.6×150mm Agilent HPLC Column Eclipse and a Varian Pro Star 230 apparatus). 2.3 Calculation of quantum efficiency Quantum efficiency is defined, according to the IUPAC recommendation [49], as the ratio of the number of molecules reacting by the number of photon interacting with the sample (Eq. (1)). (1) η q ( % ) = 100 × 2 × r ( mol m − n s − 1 ) < e a > ( Einstein m − n s − 1 ) This equation takes into account that the transfer of two electrons is required to reduce to protons and thus to produce one H2 molecule. The reaction rate of hydrogen production (r in Eq. (1)) is measured in liquid and gas phase reactors as detailed in the previous subsection. To determine the denominator, we obtain the solution of the radiative transfer equation (RTE) in the heterogeneous reactor(s) for both liquid (calculation of the so-called local volumetric rate of photon absorption; ea with n superindex in Eq. (1) equal to Eq. (3)) and gas (calculation of the so-called local superficial rate of photon absorption; ea with n superindex in Eq. (1) equal to Eq. (2)) phase processes. In Eq. (1) we used the volume or surface average values of the ea observable parameter. The RTEs for liquid (Eq. (2)) and gas phase (Eq. (3)) measured the variation of intensity (associated to a beam of x-rays at wavelength λ in the direction of a solid angle vector, Ω _ ) through a direction of the space (s). (2) d I λ , Ω _ ( x _ ) d s = − κ λ ( x _ ) I λ , Ω _ ( x _ ) − σ λ ( x _ ) I λ , Ω _ ( x _ ) + σ λ ( x _ ) 4 π ∫ Ω ′ = 4 π p ( Ω _ ' → Ω _ ) I λ , Ω _ ' d Ω _ (3) d I λ , Ω _ ( x _ ) d s = 0 Where κ λ ( x _ ) is the absorption coefficient; σ λ ( x _ ) is the dispersión coefficient; and p ( Ω _ ' → Ω _ ) is the scattering phase measured with the Henyey and Greenstein phase function, as usually carried out for titania samples [52]. These equations assume; (i) the emission radiation is negligible (at room temperature), and (ii) steady state condition during the photocatalytic processes. Eq. (3) also considers negligible the absorption (related to the absorption coefficient κ λ ( x ̲ ) ) and dispersion (related to the dispersion coefficient σ λ ( x ̲ ) ) contributions of the reaction media, i.e. the gas carrier and the reaction mixture [49]. We presented full details of the mathematical procedure to calculate the denominator of Eq. (1) in the Supporting information section. The specific catalyst(s) optical properties involved in the determination of the ea parameter at the liquid/gas phase reactions are also presented (Figs. S3 and S9) in the mentioned Supporting information section. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization results XRD patterns for the three samples under study are presented in Fig. 1 . The patterns are dominated by the anatase polymorph profile (PDF 21-1272; space group I41/amd) and only a small quantity of rutile (PDF 21-1276; space group P42/mnm) can be detected. A constant rutile concentration in the order of 5% is observed throughout the sample series. The anatase primary particle size is also constant, being ca. 13nm. Absence of XRD noble metal signals can be noticed, in accordance of the relatively limited amount of active metal present in the catalysts. The structural similitude among our samples (more precisely in the support structural characteristics) extracted from the XRD analysis is maintained also from the point of view of the surface area. BET values included in Table 1 only show a relatively mild decrease in presence of the noble metals, indicating a partial occlusion of the pores of the support by presence of the co-catalyst. The samples also present relatively similar UV spectra, as shown in Fig. 2 . The characteristic intensity decay ascribable to the titania band gap dominates the spectra presented in Fig. 2. Considering that the dominant (according to XRD) anatase phase is an indirect gap semiconductor [53], values of the corresponding band gap energy were calculated and included in Table 1. These are essentially constant having a value of 3.11±0.03eV for all samples. This corresponds to a band gap dominated, as mentioned, by the major anatase phase, with absence of noticeable modification by presence of the noble metals. Such noble metal component is not detected by any signal or contribution to the UV–vis spectra as the surface plasmon resonances in Pt and Pd cases do not render discrete peaks in the UV–vis spectrum due to the damping effect caused by d-d intraband transitions [1,3]. Instead of it, we observed a broad tail (from ca. 400 to 550nm) characteristic of Nb-doped materials and caused by the defects present at the anatase structure as a results of the charge compensation process originated by the doping process or, more precisely, the difference in formal oxidation state between Nb (+5) and Ti (+4) [54]. The fraction of defects, in this case, anion vacancies, located at the surface seems to interact with the noble metals and modify the optical properties of the catalysts, presenting large absorption capability than the bare support. To obtain information on the noble metal component we carried out a microscopy study of the materials. Fig. 3 displays representative TEM macrographs of the noble metal containing samples as well as the corresponding histograms of the Pt and Pd primary particle size. The TEM micrographs are dominated by ca. 10–15nm platelets of the titania component over which small, round-shaped metallic particles are clearly visible. These are marked with white arrows in the TEM Figure. The average value of the primary particle size (particle size histograms are also included in Fig. 3 for both Pt and Pd containing samples) is rather similar for the two materials here studied, 1.5±0.1nm. The small primary particle sizes as well as the relatively small tails observed in the histograms of Fig. 3 are both indicative of the reasonable similitude in terms of the metal surface area available for reaction. Therefore, the combination of the XRD, UV–vis and TEM studies indicates that the noble metal deposition over titania does not alter the support to a large degree and that the two metals display a similar dispersion value in the noble metal containing catalysts. 3.2 Photoactivity measurements: reaction rate and quantum efficiency observables In this section we analyze the photo-production of hydrogen for the two noble metal co-catalysts. Here we propose a Nb-doped titania support allowing UV and visible light adsorption in order to test both illumination conditions. The use of Nb-TiO2 materials for UV, visible and sunlight applications is common in photocatalysis, rendering active materials [54–58]. In a preliminary experiment, we optimized from a catalytic viewpoint the concentration of the primary noble metal to study (Pt) and the Nb-containing support. We selected Pt for the initial study because, as mentioned in the introduction, is the most widely co-catalyst utilized in the literature for hydrogen photo-production [1,2,4,5]. The optimum concentration of both Pt and Nb was selected from the analysis of the reaction rate at liquid phase (see Fig. S10 at the Supporting information section). The activity maximum was obtained with a sample having a 1wt.% of Pt and a 3mol% of Nb, which was used hereafter in the study. Fig. 4 shows the reaction rates for the liquid phase reaction (using a 3:7 CH3OH:H2O ratio) measured for the Pt and Pd noble metal containing samples and the corresponding NbTi reference under UV and Visible light excitation. Note that according to the characterization results, Pt and Pd catalysts display a rather similar particle size (Fig. 3). The plot in Fig. 4 evidences a consistent enhancement of activity (significantly larger than one order of magnitude) in presence of the noble metal. At liquid phase, Pt co-catalysts render slightly larger activity than Pd upon UV excitation while the differences are enlarged upon visible light excitation. As mentioned, negligible activity (when compared with noble metal promoted materials) is presented by the support alone in both illumination conditions. To further quantify the photocatalytic performance of the materials we calculated the efficiency parameter. To do it, we first computed the corresponding average volumetric rate of photon absorption. This observable is presented in Fig. 5 a function of two spatial coordinates (dictated by the cylindrical geometry of the liquid reactor). No significant differences are observed among the studied catalysts, as may be envisaged by their similar chemical composition and physico-chemical (particularly optical ones presented in Fig. S3 at the Supporting information section) properties. The calculated true quantum efficiency parameters for liquid phase are presented in Fig. 6 . The values displayed by the noble metal containing samples are essentially the same under UV while the Pt appears more active than Pd by ca. ×11 times under visible light. The true quantum efficiency shows that both co-catalyst displays activity under visible light excitation but the light to chemical transformation is about 30 (Pt) and 260 (Pd) times more effective under UV than visible light excitation. Therefore, calculation of the true quantum efficiency in liquid phase indicates that noble metal promoted titania samples present values near 2% for UV and below 0.1% for visible light (Fig. 6). Comparison with literature is relatively difficult. Metal-promoted titania catalysts having Pt [13,20], Cu [16,17] or Ni [59] previously published in the literature reported UV photonic or apparent rather than true quantum efficiencies, values ranging typically from ca. 2 to 10%. However, we did not find any report in the literature concerning the true quantum efficiency for hydrogen production using titania-based photocatalysts. Only Pt-promoted carbon nitride based materials presenting quantum efficiencies below 2% under sunlight-type excitation have been previously reported [60]. So, the systems here presented are in line with literature reports. For gas phase reaction, the reaction rates presented in Fig. 7 display a behaviour differing from liquid phase. In this case and in comparison with Pt, Pd shows a significantly higher activity in the gas phase process under UV excitation while both catalysts show relatively marginal activity under visible light illumination. The different, inherent units of the reaction rates at liquid and gas phase make comparison difficult. The measurement and calculation of the local superficial rate of photon absorption (presented in Fig. 8 ) allows the computation of the quantum efficiency. The corresponding true quantum efficiency values are presented in Fig. 9 . Fig. 8 indicates that samples only differ marginally in optical properties of interest in photocatalysis and thus main changes in the true quantum efficiency (Fig. 9) reflects directly the changes in chemical properties (Fig. 7). So, the higher Pd activity is directly reflected in the quantum efficiency, a factor of 2.9 times higher than the one of Pt. In the case of visible illumination, mild differences in optical properties modulate the catalytic response of the solid in the true quantum efficiency observable. In any case, Pd shows a quantum efficiency value ×3 with respect to Pt under UV but almost no response under visible illumination. As occurs in liquid phase, marked decrease of the efficiency is observed in going from UV to visible illumination (60 and 2700 times for Pt and Pd, respectively). We are not aware of any calculation of the true quantum efficiency in a gas phase process considering Pt or Pd co-catalysts, and thus the present results can not be compared with literature reports. The analysis of the true quantum efficiency (Figs. 6 and 9) suggests that Pd would render similar (liquid phase) or higher (gas phase) activity to Pt under UV, while the opposite is true under visible light illumination. We can also note that Pd has a more balance performance in liquid and gas phase upon UV excitation, presenting always reasonable reaction rates values. Contrarily, at gas phase the two co-catalyst show important differences. Under UV illumination Pd displays enhanced performance with respect to the Pt co-catalyst, and the contrary is true under visible illumination. No easy comparison between Pt and Pd can be carried out as both usually present significant activity but effects of (different) noble metal primary particle size, shape or dispersion obscure such comparison in previous publications [11,38,42]. On the other hand, we are aware of a single, previous comparison between liquid and gas phase reactors using Pd as co-catalyst but no information was presented about the exact reaction mixture as gas phase experiments were carried out with vapours from a liquid phase which were not defined in terms of alcohol to water ratio [61]. Analyzing thus the performance of the noble metals in all cases here tested, it becomes evident that Pd can be competitive with Pt under UV illumination but suffers a stronger decay under visible illumination. To uncover the roots of such behaviour we first examined the chemical products generated by the alcohol transformation (see Tables 2 and 3 for, respectively, liquid and gas phase reactions). Eqs. (4), (5), (7) correspond to the main products of the reaction, as previously observed and discussed by several authors [4,20,38,48]. These main products are formaldehyde (Eq. (4)), formic acid (Eq. (5)), and carbon dioxide (Eq. (7)), produced from methanol by hole (or hydroxyl) attack. Eq. (6a) presents the formation of methylformate from methanol, a reaction mostly observed to take place in the photo-oxidation of methanol [62] but also detected in the photo-production of hydrogen from methanol [20]. An alternative route (Eq. (6b)) for production of methylformate has been proposed using exclusively methanol [20]. The catalytic cycle closes with the production of hydrogen (2 H+ +2e− →H2). (4) CH3OH+2h+ (2OH −)→CH2O+2H+ (2H2O) (5) CH2O+H2O+2h+ (2OH −)→HCOOH+2H+ (2H2O) (6a) CH3OH+HCOOH→HCOOCH3 +H2O (6b) 2 CH3OH→HCOOCH3 +2H+ (7) HCOOH+2h+ (2OH −)→CO2 +2 H+ (2H2O) From these equations it is obvious that the chemical properties of the titania surface would affect the hydrogen production as the different products are generated in a step like mechanism where successive steps “extract” additional protons from the original methanol molecule. Note that some “secondary” products such as methylformate originated from reaction of a primary product (formic acid; Eq. (6a)) or using 2 molecules of methanol (Eq. (6b)) are commonly generated with lower co-production of hydrogen per methanol molecule compared with the other “primary” products. The co-catalyst may alter the balance among these products by producing new centers at the metal-support interface and/or altering them by electrostatic and/or electronic effects. In liquid phase, the carbon containing product distribution of the bare titania-based support is modified to a limited level by the presence of the co-catalyst, irrespective of the excitation wavelength. In fact, in the case of Pt only a small amount of methylformate can be shown as significant difference with respect to the titania catalysts. As mentioned, this product consumes methanol without co-production of hydrogen (Eq. (6a)) or with lower production than all other products (Eq. (6b)). In the case for Pd and besides the production of methylformate, we observed an increase in CO2 selectivity beyond experimental error which would thus favor the production of hydrogen per methanol molecule converted. So, the presence of both noble metal co-catalysts at the titania surface alters the chemical transformation of methanol (minor production of methylformate) with respect to the bare support, rendering a low per methanol molecule production of hydrogen. In the case of Pd, a more important but (in any case) modest increase in CO2 generation with concomitant enhanced hydrogen production is additional observed in Table 2. The production of hydrogen per unit methanol molecule would be thus favored in presence of a Pd co-catalyst (according to Table 2 and considering the number of hydrogen molecules produced concomitantly to each carbon-containing product, by factors of ca. 1.15 – UV – and 1.05 – visible – with respect to Pt). However, this is not reflected in a higher quantum efficiency for the Pd containing material under both illumination conditions (Fig. 6). Nevertheless, we note that this factor would account for variations in activity up to 20% in our case and that such factor is usually dismissed in the literature. For gas phase, formaldehyde appears as a minor product under UV excitation together with methylformate and carbon dioxide for all excitation wavelengths. CO2 is the main product for all samples and illumination conditions, with potential, concomitant enhancement of the hydrogen yield with respect to the liquid phase. We observed slightly lower values for CO2 selectivity upon visible light with respect to UV illumination. Both noble metal co-catalysts facilitate the production of CO2 with respect to the bare reference, this occurring without practical differences between them (a slightly larger selectivity to the total oxidation product is presented for Pd in the UV case). Thus, from a chemical point of view, the production of hydrogen (per unit methanol molecule) may be slightly favored in presence of a Pd co-catalyst but exclusively under UV illumination (according to Table 3 by a factor of ca. 1.1). The second main property which would rationalize the differences between the Pt and Pd co-catalysts relates to their effect in charge handling properties and particularly in their effect in charge recombination after light excitation. Photoluminescence experiments presented in Fig. 10 attempt to shed some light into this issue. Excitation under UV (365nm) shows the typical photoluminescence spectra of the reference sample, dominated by the anatase component. Such spectrum is composed in fact by two main transitions corresponding to the annihilation of conduction band free electrons with trapped holes and valence band free holes with trapped electrons [63]. The transitions are usually called green and red due to the average energy of the transition, ca. 450nm from the green and above 500nm for the red. In any case, both co-catalysts present lower photoluminescence intensity than the bare titania reference, indicating that electron capture with the noble metal efficiency enhance the average lifetime of the charge carriers generated into the titania component upon UV excitation. Pd makes this job more efficiency than Pt. Upon visible excitation (425nm; Fig. 10), the photoluminescence profiles display a strong decay from the excitation line. These decay curves are essentially featureless, with a small shoulders at ca. 510 and 535nm indicating the presence of localized states likely associated to defects at the titania component [50,51]. These defects are (at least in part) located at the surface as their charge handling properties are affected by the presence of the noble metals. In any case and as occurring under UV excitation, Pd seems to decrease charge recombination to a larger extent than Pt. Summarizing, the study of the methanol evolution though the analysis of the reaction selectivity as well as the charge handling properties of the solids would indicate that Pd could be a better co-catalytic than Pt when comparing similar primary particle size materials. This appears in agreement with previous information based in noble metal surface normalized reaction rates [38]. The joint combination of the two facts (selectivity and charge handling and recombination) would be determinant to justify a general better performance of Pd presented under UV illumination. Note however, that differences among co-catalysts in true quantum efficiency are not so obvious at liquid phase, indicating than other phenomena may be of significance to rationalize the results. In this context we can mention that the role of metal-support interface sites in the activation of the different carbon-containing intermediates has been spectroscopically examined in recent contributions [64,65] and this issue may be of significance in our case. Such studies would indicate that the participation of OH species of the interface may be critical to render highly active sites for the sacrificial agent transformation. The behavior of such species would be defined by the specific metal presented at the interface with titania. Opposite to the UV case, under visible illumination Pd can not provide the same performance than Pt in both liquid and gas phase processes as measured by the true quantum efficiency (Figs. 6 and 9). This is against the most efficient production of hydrogen per methanol molecule and to the somewhat better charge handling properties obtained in presence of Pd and visible light illumination. These two facts suggest that the Pt-titania interface may be significantly most efficient, presenting active sites with significantly higher reaction rates. Such differences in the interface (active) centers would thus consider activity (reaction rate) but also may explain selectivity differences between Pt and Pd co-catalysts, accounting for the differences in the selectivity observed in the final C-containing products of the reaction (Tables 2 and 3). This proposal requires however further study. 4 Conclusions In this work we tested the performance of Nb-doped titania-based Pt and Pd co-catalysts in the liquid and gas phase production of hydrogen from methanol:water mixtures. The characterization of the materials showed that the support does not suffer significant alteration by the deposition of the two co-catalyst and that the noble metals present similar particle size in the two cases studied. The analysis of the hydrogen photo-production was carried out in terms of the true quantum efficiency in order to render meaningful results. Significant higher values (three orders of magnitude superior) are obtained in the liquid phase with respect to the gas phase. Also the efficiency decay typically observed from UV to visible illumination conditions is significantly smaller (about one order of magnitude) in the liquid phase reaction. The comparison of Pt and Pd co-catalyst quantum efficiency values for hydrogen photo-production was analyzed in terms of the carbon selectivity of the sacrificial molecule transformation and the charge handling capability of the materials. The first would take into account variations of the true quantum efficiency though our samples and illumination conditions by factors between 1.05 and 1.2. This factor is thus not driving the experimental differences observed between the two noble metals in both liquid and gas phase reactions. The second seems of critical importance to drive the general better performance of Pd vs. Pt under UV illumination in the two (liquid and gas) processes studied. However, the efficiency results, particularly under visible illumination, indicate that other, unknown properties are of importance in driving the photo-production of hydrogen in presence of noble metal co-catalysts. The metal-titania interface and its role in the activation of the sacrificial methanol molecule may have a relevant role for controlling the performance (activity in hydrogen photo-production and selectivity in the transformation of the sacrificial alcohol molecule) of these two noble metal titania-based catalysts. coredata.dc:description: In this work we compare the performance of platinum and palladium co-catalysts supported on Nb-doped titania materials for the photo-generation of hydrogen using methanol as sacrificial agent. Liquid and gas phase processes are considered. The catalysts physico-chemical properties were characterized by a combination of X-ray diffraction, UV–vis and photoluminescence spectroscopies and transmission electron microscopy, and their photocatalytic performance assessed through the analysis of the optical properties, the measurement of the reaction rates and subsequent computation of the true quantum efficiency in both liquid and gas phase reactors. Using Pt and Pd containing catalysts having similar primary noble metal particle size we compare the two co-catalysts performance in terms of the carbon containing product selectivity of the methanol photo-transformation and the overall performance of the materials in the photon to chemical transformation as measured through the true quantum efficiency. The work shows that Pd displays competitive performance with respect to Pt under UV illumination but not under visible light. The physico-chemical analysis of the solids and particularly the measurement of the charge carrier handling and recombination through photoluminescence at several wavelengths indicate the important role played by charge recombination upon UV illumination but also that other phenomena need to be considered under visible illumination to fully explain the photo-catalytic evolution of hydrogen in noble metal containing catalysts.
coredata.dc:title: UV and visible light driven H2 photo-production using Nb-doped TiO2: Comparing Pt and Pd co-catalysts
